title: What does it mean to be French? How a cyclone set the debate adrift
summary: The cyclone that hit Mayotte on December 14, 2024, has reignited the semantic battle over French identity, phobias and concerns about cultural diversity. Especially when the other is an immigrant and the object of fantasies in a Republic questioning its future.

title: Mark Carney to become Canada’s next prime minister amid trade war and US annexation threat
summary: Former central banker Mark Carney will be Canada’s next prime minister after winning the Liberal Party leadership on Sunday. He takes over as the country faces economic turmoil, a looming election, and rising tensions with the US over Donald Trump’s trade war and inflammatory talk of annexation.

title: Syrians describe the violence targeting Alawite minority: 'Tomorrow, there won't be a man left alive in my village'
summary: Interim president Ahmed al-Sharaa appealed for civil peace on Sunday, following the deaths of hundreds in deadly clashes. Le Monde contacted several residents who recounted abuses perpetrated against members of the Alawite minority, from which the Assad clan descended.

title: Israel stops supplying electricity to Gaza
summary: The country's energy minister said Sunday he had given instructions to halt the electricity supply 'immediately,' justifying the move as a way to pressure Hamas into releasing Israeli hostages.

title: Article 5, the pillar of NATO undermined by Donald Trump
summary: The text providing for the mutual commitment of the members of the Atlantic Alliance, now contested by the US president, was invoked only once in history, in the aftermath of the attacks of September 11, 2001.

title: Carlos Peñafiel, the Chilean artisan behind Lemaire's sculpted leather
summary: Inspired by nature, Peñafiel's sculpted leather creations take shape as bags, shoes and voluptuously curved furniture. At 75, the artisan is showcasing his work from March 3 to 28 at Lemaire's Paris boutique, celebrating his craftsmanship and playful vision.

title: Two days of clashes and revenge killings leave more than 1,000 people dead in Syria
summary: The clashes, which erupted Thursday, marked a major escalation in the challenge to the new government in Damascus, three months after insurgents took authority after removing Assad from power.

title: 'There is an ambiguity between Pope Francis's diplomacy, in a sense close to Trump's, and the Vatican's, which is more traditional'
summary: In an interview with Le Monde, the political scientist François Mabille analyzes the ambiguous diplomacy of a Curia torn between the defense of international law and the pope's standpoint, who prefers to dialogue with everyone, including aggressors.

title: Germany's Merz repeats he's open to France extending nuclear deterrent
summary: 'We simply must become stronger together in nuclear deterrence in Europe,' Merz, expected to become Germany's next chancellor, said in an interview as the continent seeks to respond to US President Donald Trump's upending of the transatlantic alliance.

title: Behind Musk's DOGE, a collection of potential conflicts of interest
summary: The Department of Government Efficiency currently intervenes in the affairs of agencies regulating the billionaire's companies, from X to Tesla to SpaceX.

title: Republican camp is increasingly hostile to Musk's cuts
summary: Trump's public-sector job cuts and tariffs have cast a cloud of uncertainty over the economy. Employment held steady in February, but the anxiety is palpable. A cabinet meeting even turned into a confrontation between administration members and the Tesla CEO.

title: Can tap water be effectively treated against PFAS and other pollutants?
summary: From moringa seeds to reverse osmosis and activated carbon filters, several systems are available to eliminate certain molecules, with varying levels of efficiency and cost.

title: Release of President Yoon exacerbates tensions in South Korea
summary: Released on March 8 on a technicality, the leader is still awaiting the Constitutional Court's decision on the impeachment motion voted against him after his aborted declaration of martial law. His supporters and opponents are more mobilized than ever.

title: Russia claims gains in Kursk as Zelensky says 'committed' to talks
summary: The three-year-long war is now at a critical juncture for Kyiv after Trump suspended US military aid following his public falling-out with Zelensky last week.

title: Spain is successfully rolling out the red carpet for foreign film shoots
summary: 'The Walking Dead,' 'Lucky Luke,' 'The Fantastic 4'... Since 2020, the Spanish government has been attracting international film crews with tax credits, industry aid and administrative facilities. Shoots are multiplying, to the benefit of the local economy.

title: French actor François Cluzet: 'My father, my brother and I were serial liars. I got rid of it through acting'
summary: "I wouldn't have got here if..." Every week, Le Monde interviews a well-known person about a decisive moment in their life. The French actor takes a look back at a childhood full of lies.

title: French research groups urged to welcome scientists fleeing US
summary: The Trump administration has sought to dismiss hundreds of federal workers focusing on health and climate research. French Minister for Higher Education and Research Philippe Baptiste said, 'We would naturally wish to welcome a certain number of them.'

title: US Secret Service shoots armed man near White House says spokesman
summary: The man had been hospitalized and his condition was 'unknown,' spokesman Anthony Guglielmi said in a statement that did not specify whether the White House or Trump may have been the intended target

title: France to send nearly €200 million in military aid to Ukraine
summary: France will provide Ukraine with a new €195 million military aid package funded by interest from frozen Russian assets, Defense Minister Sébastien Lecornu said Sunday. The package includes 155mm shells and air-to-surface missiles as Ukraine faces setbacks from the US weapons suspension.

title: The Chinese paradox: How becoming the world leader in green energy slows climate progress
summary: China missed its 2024 target for reducing carbon intensity. The clean energy sector has become the engine of economic growth, yet manufacturing solar panels and wind turbines requires vast amounts of energy.

title: Columbia University protest leader arrested by immigration officers amid crackdown on pro-Palestinian demonstrators
summary: Mahmoud Khalil, a prominent organizer of protests at Columbia University against Israel's war on Gaza, was arrested by immigration officers on Saturday, a campus union said. His detention follows former President Donald Trump's pledge to deport foreign students involved in pro-Palestinian demonstrations, as federal authorities escalate their response to campus activism.

title: France consolidates its position as the world's second-largest arms exporter
summary: Ukraine has become the leading buyer of weapons on a European continent driven to rearm by the Russian threat. The US remains by far the leading supplier to the international war market.

title: Romania's electoral bureau bars far-right candidate Georgescu from presidential re-run
summary: Romania's electoral bureau has rejected far-right candidate Calin Georgescu's bid for the re-run of last year's annulled presidential election, citing legal violations tied to the original vote's nullification. The decision triggered violent protests in Bucharest, where police clashed with his supporters.

title: Paris Fashion Week: Japanese designers, or the reinvention of the wardrobe
summary: Kenzo's playful irreverence, Issey Miyake's colorful lightness and Comme des Garçons' lesson in style were the highlights of the presentations of the Fall/Winter 2025-2026 collections.

title: Russian officials gift meat grinders to mothers of fallen soldiers, sparking outrage
summary: A local branch of Russia’s ruling party in the Murmansk region has come under fire for gifting meat grinders to mothers of fallen soldiers. The gesture drew widespread criticism, as 'meat grinder' is also a Russian term for the brutal tactic of sending waves of infantry into battle.
